perturbation.original_text: Any Dispute which remains unresolved within sixty (60) days after the date of such written notice shall be submitted to the China International Economic and Trade Arbitration Commission (the “Commission”) to be finally settled by arbitration in Beijing, PRC in accordance with the Commission’s then effective rules (the “Rules”) and this Section 10.12.
perturbation.changed_text: Any Dispute which remains unresolved within fifteen (15) days after the date of such written notice shall be submitted to the China International Economic and Trade Arbitration Commission (the “Commission”) to be finally settled by arbitration in Beijing, PRC in accordance with the Commission’s then effective rules (the “Rules”) and this Section 10.12.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows for a 60-day period for dispute resolution through friendly consultation. Reducing this period to 15 days may be seen as unreasonably short under PRC law, potentially hindering the parties' ability to resolve disputes amicably and increasing the likelihood of arbitration. This could be viewed as a violation of good faith negotiation principles.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Principles of Contract Law in the People's Republic of China

perturbation.original_text: If any Party pays any taxes that should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party shall reimburse such Party within seven (7) days after its receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.changed_text: If any Party pays any taxes that should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party shall reimburse such Party within one hundred and eighty (180) days after its receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates a reimbursement period of 7 days for tax payments made by one party on behalf of the other. Changing this to 180 days could violate tax regulations in the PRC, which may require more prompt reimbursement of tax-related expenses to ensure compliance and avoid penalties. This is contradictory with Article 10.1 of the contract: Each Party shall be responsible for taxes that should be borne by it in accordance with applicable Law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Tax Laws of the People's Republic of China

perturbation.original_text: Licensee shall remove any offending Content, including, but not limited to, any illegal materials, pornographic, obscene or sexually explicit materials, materials of a violent nature, or politically sensitive materials, from such websites as soon as possible after it becomes aware of such offending Content but in no event later than the timeframe prescribed by the Governmental Authority after receipt of oral or written notice from Licensor or such Governmental Authority.
perturbation.changed_text: Licensee shall remove any offending Content, including, but not limited to, any illegal materials, pornographic, obscene or sexually explicit materials, materials of a violent nature, or politically sensitive materials, from such websites at their earliest convenience.
perturbation.explanation: The original text has a standard about the Governmental Authority. The changed text replacing it will violates the Internet Content Regulations of the People's Republic of China, which require specific and immediate actions for removing prohibited content. Removing the defined timeframe and replacing it with 'at their earliest convenience' introduces ambiguity and allows for delays, potentially violating content control laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Internet Content Regulations of the People's Republic of China
